bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Myron [s.n.], April 14, 1931

div1.p: Laura Carter sends her cousin Myron biographical material on Henry Carter, claiming that his work helped to determine the direction of Reed's.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Myron [s.n.], April 14, 1931

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
April 14, 1931.

div1.p:
In reply to your letter of April 11th., I am herewith sending
you some much-prized biographic material on Father, which I shall be
grateful to have you return me by registered mail as soon as you have
finished with it.

Of the material enclosed, Frost's “Notes” give the most accurate
and detailed account of Father's contributions to Sanitary Science, but
each of the other enclosures give some “side-lights,” which help to
illuminate some particular part of the subject.

The best way to express the relation of Father's and Reed's work
is that “Carter's work determined the direction of Reed's” or “helped to
determine the direction”... This you will see for yourself after read-
ing the enclosed material.

Were I you, I should certainly put in Reed's name as well as
Father's--they belong together in the yellow fever work, and not to put
in Reed's (when stressing Father's yellow fever work) would be an error--
historically and in other ways.

Of Father's work on malaria control, before, during and after
the World War, and of his other contributions to the welfare of humanity,
you will find mention in the enclosed material--and better mention than
I could make in the limited time at my disposal. I am at present in
daily--nay hourly!--expectation of the arrival of the page proof of
Father's book and have to keep in a state of “preparedness” for the long,
hard hours of intensive work that are always necessary in order to re-
turn the material to the publisher as soon as possible. The galley proof
has all been read and corrected (a) by the proof readers of the pub-
lishers (Williams and Wilkins (medical publishers) of Baltimore: (b) by
Mr. van Wesep, Chief of Information Service of the Rockefeller Foundation:
(c) by Frost and myself (joint editors). It should then be accurate!

I should love to visit you all in Halifax, but “until this...be
overpast” I dare not leave Washington even for a day, lest I hold up
the publication of the book.

Please tell Bessie that Aunt Mary is with me for a few days. She
joins me in love to you all. Aunt Nannie (her older sister) died, very
peacefully, on March 17th., after a short illness.

Hoping that the enclosed material may fill all your requirements,
and assuring you that I can give you no higher proof of my confidence, than
to lend it to you!
div1.closer: Your affectionate cousin, Laura A. Carter 9 enclosures.
